title: 107_hr3768
content: The Act titled "Worker Retraining Incentive Act of 2002" introduces a refundable credit for employees who complete a training program under the Trade Act of 1974 to offset a portion of their Social Security taxes. The Worker Retraining Incentive Act of 2002 offers a credit against social security taxes for eligible individuals who complete a Trade Adjustment Assistance program under the Trade Act of 1974. The credit is limited if the individual's wages and compensation for the 1-year period exceed $60,000. The Worker Retraining Incentive Act of 2002 provides a credit against social security taxes for eligible individuals who complete a Trade Adjustment Assistance program under the Trade Act of 1974. The credit is limited if the individual's wages and compensation for the 1-year period exceed $60,000. An individual is not eligible if reemployed with the same employer in a similar position as before the program. All persons treated as a single employer are considered as one for this purpose. The term 'social security taxes' refers to the taxes imposed on amounts received by a taxpayer during the taxable year, based on specific rates outlined in different sections of the tax code. The term 'social security taxes' excludes taxes eligible for a special refund under section 6413(c) and includes amounts paid under agreements with foreign affiliates. No credit is allowed to dependents. No credit is allowed to dependents for whom a deduction under section 151 is allowable to another taxpayer for the same taxable year. Technical amendments are made to section 1324(b) of title 31, United States Code, and the table of sections for subpart C of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1. SEC. 35 provides a credit for social security taxes borne by employees who complete training under the Trade Act of 1974. SEC. 36 addresses overpayments of tax. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2002. SEC. 3 introduces a credit for employer social security taxes paid for employees hired after completing training programs under the Trade Act of 1974. "SEC. 45G introduces a credit for employer social security taxes paid for employees hired after completing training programs under the Trade Act of 1974." The employer trade adjustment assistance hiring credit is determined by the qualified social security taxes paid for eligible employees during their first year of work. No credit is allowed if an employee's total wages and compensation exceed $60,000 in that period. Qualified social security tax refers to taxes paid for eligible employees in a taxable year. The employer trade adjustment assistance hiring credit is based on the qualified social security taxes paid for eligible employees in a taxable year. This includes taxes imposed on amounts paid to employees by the taxpayer during the calendar year. The term 'social security taxes' does not include taxes for which the taxpayer is entitled to a special refund. The employer trade adjustment assistance hiring credit is based on qualified social security taxes paid for eligible employees. Special refunds of such taxes are not included. Amounts paid under agreements with foreign affiliates are treated as taxes. An eligible employee is defined as an individual eligible for the credit. No double benefits are allowed, and taxpayers can elect not to claim the credit for a taxable year. The trade adjustment assistance hiring credit is added to Section 38(b) of the tax code, allowing taxpayers to elect not to claim the credit for a taxable year. Section 45G provides a credit for employer social security taxes paid for employees hired after completing training programs under the Trade Act of 1974. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2002.
